LAKE GENEVA, WI 53147

citations.narrative:
On 7/27/25, a female Nilgai named "Haley", approximately 1 year old, reportedly bit a member of the public while inside
the Boma area where public can directly interact with the animals. The woman was bitten on the hand, breaking the skin
and causing it to bleed. The incident was documented on facility records and there was no injury to the animal. The facility
representative conveyed that "Haley" is one of the older animals in the area and will be moved soon to the larger safari
area once it is safe to introduce her. The facility representative also stated that she was bottle-raised and is more
"mouthy" with visitors than some of the other animals.
During the routine unannounced inspection, inspectors observed animals including water buffalo, bison, brahma cattle,
ostriches, and elands attempting to put their heads in vehicles to eat feed pellets. During inspection, an eland's entire
head except for the horns was observed to be inside a visitor's vehicle. Additionally, a photo on social media by a member
of the public was shared with inspection staff that showed a Brahma cow with its horns stuck in the vehicle. The cow
needed assistance from a facility attendant to remove the head from the vehicle. According to the facility representative,
the vehicle honked their horn as instructed and the attendant nearby came to help. No injuries to the cow nor any
members of the public resulted from the incident.
During public exhibition, any animal must be handled so there is minimal risk of harm to the animals and public, with
sufficient barriers between the animals and general viewing public. Direct animal access by the public creates an
environment for injuries to possibly occur. Allowing animals to put their heads directly into vehicles also does not protect
the animals or public from harm or injury. Correct by ensuring that animals are exhibited with sufficient barriers and or
distance to protect both the animals and public.
***Correct starting 7/31/25 going forward.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the facility representatives.
Additional Inspectors:
LYNNE WHITE-SHIM, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER
Lemnique Wafer, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER n

narrative:
2.131(c)(1)  Critical
   
Handling of animals. 
On 7/27/25, a female Nilgai named "Haley", approximately 1 year old, reportedly bit a member of the public while inside 
the Boma area where public can directly interact with the animals. The woman was bitten on the hand, breaking the skin 
and causing it to bleed. The incident was documented on facility records and there was no injury to the animal. The facility 
representative conveyed that "Haley" is one of the older animals in the area and will be moved soon to the larger safari 
area once it is safe to introduce her. The facility representative also stated that she was bottle-raised and is more 
"mouthy" with visitors than some of the other animals.  
 
During the routine unannounced inspection, inspectors observed animals including water buffalo, bison, brahma cattle, 
ostriches, and elands attempting to put their heads in vehicles to eat feed pellets. During inspection, an eland's entire 
head except for the horns was observed to be inside a visitor's vehicle. Additionally, a photo on social media by a member 
of the public was shared with inspection staff that showed a Brahma cow with its horns stuck in the vehicle. The cow 
needed assistance from a facility attendant to remove the head from the vehicle. According to the facility representative, 
the vehicle honked their horn as instructed and the attendant nearby came to help. No injuries to the cow nor any 
members of the public resulted from the incident.  
 
During public exhibition, any animal must be handled so there is minimal risk of harm to the animals and public, with 
sufficient barriers between the animals and general viewing public. Direct animal access by the public creates an 
environment for injuries to possibly occur. Allowing animals to put their heads directly into vehicles also does not protect 
the animals or public from harm or injury. Correct by ensuring that animals are exhibited with sufficient barriers and or 
distance to protect both the animals and public.  
 
***Correct starting 7/31/25 going forward. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the facility representatives.

Additional Inspectors: 
LYNNE WHITE-SHIM, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER 
Lemnique Wafer, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER n
